title: ECI JobBOSS Customer Portal
text: As the JobBOSS support team we have access to the ECI JobBOSS Customer Portal:- ECI Customer Portal Home (ecisolutions.com) Click the Log in You can Search for key words:- Click on Support>Create Case to log an issue:
description:
As the JobBOSS support team we have access to the ECI JobBOSS Customer Portal:-


ECI Customer Portal Home (ecisolutions.com) 


Click the Log in


You can Search for key words:-


Click on Support>Create Case to log an issue:

title: Requesting a JobBOSS key
text: JobBOSS keys are generated by ECI software in the USA. You need to send an email to MFGLicense@ecisolutions.com to request a JobBOSS Client or Feature key. ECI solutions only issue 1 year keys, if you require a temporary key can issue a Client key from another customer as they are generic and only contain the expiry date.
description:
JobBOSS keys are generated by ECI software in the USA.


You need to send an email to MFGLicense@ecisolutions.com to request a JobBOSS Client or Feature key.


ECI solutions only issue 1 year keys, if you require a temporary key can issue a Client key from another customer as they are generic and only contain the expiry date.

title: SIIM Export Error during processing - Cannot load document for export
text: This error can be a result of a duplicate address for the Customer in JobBOSS. The K3 PIIM product reads upper and lower case characters as the same. i.e. JOBBOSS; jobboss is a duplicate. Connect onto the Customers SQL server and open the JobBOSS client and open Accounts Receivable>Customer Invoices and enter the invoice number to find the Customer:- Go to the Customers option and select Addresses. In this example the duplicate is FROME and frome: - Log into SQL Server Management Studio and open the live JobBOSS database and navigate to the dbo.Address and amend the duplicate in Ship_To_ID: - Advise the Customer to run the SIIM Export again.
description:
This error can be a result of a duplicate address for the Customer in JobBOSS.


The K3 PIIM product reads upper and lower case characters as the same. i.e. JOBBOSS; jobboss is a duplicate.


Connect onto the Customers SQL server and open the JobBOSS client and open Accounts Receivable>Customer Invoices and enter the invoice number to find the Customer:-


Go to the Customers option and select Addresses. 



In this example the duplicate is FROME and frome: -


Log into SQL Server Management Studio and open the  live JobBOSS database and navigate to the dbo.Address and amend the duplicate in Ship_To_ID: -




Advise the Customer to run the SIIM Export again.

title: JobBOSS 18.1 Role Security
description:
JobBOSS 18.1 Role Security

Table Definitions

[JB_User]

 

[JB_Database]

 

[User_Databases]

 

[Feature_Register]

 

[Access_Type]

 

[Security_Group]

 

[Group_Feature_Access]

 

[Group_feature_access_data]

 

[User_feature_access]

 

[ObjectID] is a foreign key to the [User_Databases] table.

 

[User_SecurityGroups]

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Descriptions

Code

Examples

No examples in current data

 

 

[Access_Type].[Access_Level]

Current values taken from [Access_Type] table are:

 

Access_id

Access_Name

Access_Level

2

Note

Since Access Levels are defined within the [Access_Type] table, they are potentially subject to change in future JobBOSS releases.

 

 

 

[User_Databases].[Use_group_permissions]

 

The Permissions tab under User Administration shows the checkbox Override Group Permissions.

 

The [User_Databases] table definition includes the column [Use_group_permissions].  This is the inverse of the checkbox value.

 

Override Group Permissions

[Use_group_permissions]

Checked

0

Unchecked

1

 

 

[User_Databases].[Rights]

Prior to the changes for made for Role Security, rights for each User / Database combination were maintained in [User_Databases].[Rights].  The [Rights] column is now redundant.

 

 

Group & User Security

  • Security Groups apply system-wide and are not associated with any given database.   Permissions defined for a Group are stored in the [Group_Feature_Access] table.

 

Note:

There is also a [Group_feature_access_data] which stores very similar data to the [Group_Feature_Access] table.  From observation, it appears that the [Group_Feature_Access] table contains the most up-to-date information.

 

  • User Security assignments are database-specific.  Permissions defined for User / Database combinations are stored in the [User_feature_access] table.

 

  • The Override Group Permissions setting controls whether or not permissions can be assigned at the User / Database level, overriding permissions assigned to any Groups that the User belongs to.  Only if this option is NOT set, can permissions be assigned at the User / Database level.

 

  • If no permissions are assigned to a given activity,  the Access Level for that activity is ‘No Access’.  The activity does not inherit the Access Level of its parent function.

 

  • When multiple Security Groups are assigned to a User / Database, the effective permission that applies to a given feature is inherited from the Group having the highest permission setting for that feature.

E.g.

Security Group ‘Test 2’:

 

Security Group ‘Test Group’:

 

User with Security Groups ‘Test 2’ and ‘Test Group’:

 

 

SIIM / PIIM Security

‘Order Processing’ / ‘Job Entry’ / ‘Pricing’ is the permission set used by SIIM / PIIM.

 

 

 

T-Sql Scripts

Queries on Legacy [Rights] Column

-- Rights Offset for Module

DECLARE @Module varchar(50)

 

SET @Module = 'Order Processing'

 

SELECT [Offset] FROM [Feature_Register] WHERE [Name] = @Module AND [Type] = 0

 

GO  -- Result = 18

 

 

-- Rights Offset for Function

 

DECLARE @Module varchar(50)

DECLARE @Function varchar(50)

 

SET @Module = 'Order Processing'

SET @Function = 'Job Entry'

 

SELECT [FR].Offset

FROM [Feature_Register] [MR] -- Module Register

INNER JOIN [Feature_Register] [FR] ON [MR].[FeatureID] = [FR].[ParentID] -- Feature Register

WHERE [MR].[Name] = @Module AND [MR].[Type] = 0

AND [FR].[Name] = @Function AND [FR].[Type] = 1

 

GO  -- Result = 19

 

 

-- Rights Offset for Activity

 

DECLARE @Module varchar(50)

DECLARE @Function varchar(50)

DECLARE @Activity varchar(50)

 

SET @Module = 'Order Processing'

SET @Function = 'Job Entry'

SET @Activity = 'Pricing'

 

 

SELECT [AR].Offset

FROM [Feature_Register] [MR] -- Module Register

INNER JOIN Feature_Register [FR] ON [MR].[FeatureID] = [FR].[ParentID] -- Feature Register

INNER JOIN Feature_Register [AR] ON [FR].[FeatureID] = [AR].[ParentID] -- Activity Register

WHERE [MR].[Name] = @Module AND [MR].[Type] = 0

AND [FR].[Name] = @Function AND [FR].[Type] = 1

AND [AR].[Name] = @Activity AND [AR].[Type] = 2

 

GO  -- Result = 23

 

 

-- Rights for Activity

 

DECLARE @Offset int

 

SET @Offset = 23 -- Order Processing / Job Entry / Pricing

 

SELECT [value] = SUBSTRING([UD].[Rights], (@Offset + 1) * 2 - 1, 1)

FROM [User_Databases] [UD]

INNER JOIN [JB_Database] [D] ON [UD].[DatabaseID] = [D].[DatabaseID]

WHERE [UD].UserID = 'SIIM' AND [D].[Name] = 'TRAINING'

 

GO

 

 

-- Set Rights string with value of '4' for Order Processing / Job Entry / Pricing

 

UPDATE [UD] SET Rights = --DECLARE @activityName varchar(50)

 

--SET @userID = 'SIIM'

----SET @databaseID = '{BA14FA40-1FEE-4FCE-950C-44BBC9B01F8F}' --PRODUCTION

----SET @databaseID = '{9A415D72-04EB-4A51-9EF4-DD475970525C}' --TRAINING

--SET @databaseName = 'PRODUCTION'

--SET @moduleName = 'Order Processing'

--SET @functionName = 'Job Entry'

--SET @activityName = 'Pricing'

 

--SELECT @databaseID = [DatabaseID] FROM [JB_Database] WHERE [Name] = @databaseName

 

--SELECT [JBSettings].[dbo].[ufk3_EffectiveUserDatabasePermissions] (@userID, @databaseID, @moduleName, @functionName, @activityName)

 

-- Drop existing User Function

IF OBJECT_ID(N'[dbo].[ufk3_EffectiveUserDatabasePermissions]', N'FN') IS NOT NULL

BEGIN

  DROP FUNCTION [dbo].[ufk3_EffectiveUserDatabasePermissions]

END

GO

 

-- Re-create User Function

CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[ufk3_EffectiveUserDatabasePermissions]

(

@userID varchar(50),

@databaseID varchar(50),

@moduleName varchar(50),

@functionName varchar(50),

@activityName varchar(50)

)

RETURNS int

AS

BEGIN

  DECLARE @moduleID varchar(50)

  DECLARE @functionID varchar(50)

  DECLARE @activityID varchar(50)

  DECLARE @objectID uniqueidentifier

  DECLARE @overrideGroupPermissions bit

  DECLARE @groupAccessId int

  DECLARE @accessID int

  DECLARE @accessLevel int

 

  -- determine feature IDs for activity, function and module

  SELECT @activityID = [Activity_Register].[FeatureID], @functionID = [Function_Register].[FeatureID], @moduleID = [Module_Register].[FeatureID]

  FROM Feature_Register AS [Module_Register]

  LEFT OUTER JOIN Feature_Register AS [Function_Register] ON [Module_Register].[FeatureID] = [Function_Register].[ParentID]

  LEFT OUTER JOIN Feature_Register AS [Activity_Register] ON [Function_Register].[FeatureID] = [Activity_Register].[ParentID]

  WHERE [Module_Register].Name = @moduleName

  AND [Function_Register].Name = @functionName

  AND [Activity_Register].Name = @activityName

 

  -- determine object ID for user / database combination

  SELECT @objectID = [UD].[ObjectID], @overrideGroupPermissions = CASE WHEN [UD].[Use_group_permissions] = 1 THEN 0 ELSE 1 END

  FROM [User_Databases] [UD]

  WHERE [UD].UserID = @userID AND [UD].[DatabaseID] = @databaseID

 

 

  -- get group-based access IDs

  --

 

  -- if nothing for function, get group access ID for module

  IF LEN(@functionName) = 0

    SELECT @groupAccessID = MAX([GFA].[Access_Id])

    FROM [Group_Feature_Access] [GFA]

    INNER JOIN [User_SecurityGroups] [USG] ON [GFA].[Group_ID] = [USG].[Group_ID]

    WHERE [USG].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [GFA].[FeatureID] = @moduleID

    GROUP BY [GFA].[FeatureID]

  ELSE

  BEGIN

    -- if nothing for activity, get group access ID for function

    IF LEN(@activityName) = 0

      SELECT @groupAccessID = MAX([GFA].[Access_Id])

      FROM [Group_Feature_Access] [GFA]

      INNER JOIN [User_SecurityGroups] [USG] ON [GFA].[Group_ID] = [USG].[Group_ID]

      WHERE [USG].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [GFA].[FeatureID] = @functionID

      GROUP BY [GFA].[FeatureID]

 

    ELSE

      --get group access ID for activity

      SELECT @groupAccessID = MAX([GFA].[Access_Id])

      FROM [Group_Feature_Access] [GFA]

      INNER JOIN [User_SecurityGroups] [USG] ON [GFA].[Group_ID] = [USG].[Group_ID]

      WHERE [USG].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [GFA].[FeatureID] = @activityID

      GROUP BY [GFA].[FeatureID]

  END

 

  ----get group access ID for activity

  --IF LEN(@activityID) > 0

  --   SELECT @groupAccessID = MAX([GFA].[Access_Id])

  --   FROM [Group_Feature_Access] [GFA]

  --   INNER JOIN [User_SecurityGroups] [USG] ON [GFA].[Group_ID] = [USG].[Group_ID]

  --   WHERE [USG].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [GFA].[FeatureID] = @activityID

  --   GROUP BY [GFA].[FeatureID]

 

  ---- if nothing for activity, get group access ID for function

  --IF @groupAccessID IS NULL AND LEN(@functionID) > 0

  --   SELECT @groupAccessID = MAX([GFA].[Access_Id])

  --   FROM [Group_Feature_Access] [GFA]

  --   INNER JOIN [User_SecurityGroups] [USG] ON [GFA].[Group_ID] = [USG].[Group_ID]

  --   WHERE [USG].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [GFA].[FeatureID] = @functionID

  --   GROUP BY [GFA].[FeatureID]

 

  ---- if nothing for function, get group access ID for module

  --IF @groupAccessID IS NULL

  --   SELECT @groupAccessID = MAX([GFA].[Access_Id])

  --   FROM [Group_Feature_Access] [GFA]

  --   INNER JOIN [User_SecurityGroups] [USG] ON [GFA].[Group_ID] = [USG].[Group_ID]

  --   WHERE [USG].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [GFA].[FeatureID] = @moduleID

  --   GROUP BY [GFA].[FeatureID]

 

 

  -- get user-based access IDs

  --

 

  -- if nothing for function, get user access ID for module

  IF @overrideGroupPermissions = 1 AND LEN(@functionName) = 0

    SELECT @accessID = [Access_id]

    FROM [User_feature_access] [UFA]

    WHERE [UFA].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [UFA].[FeatureID] = @moduleID

  ELSE

  BEGIN

    -- if nothing for activity, get user access ID for function

    IF @overrideGroupPermissions = 1 AND LEN(@activityName) = 0

      SELECT @accessID = [Access_id]

      FROM [User_feature_access] [UFA]

      WHERE [UFA].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [UFA].[FeatureID] = @functionID

 

    ELSE

      -- get user access ID for activity

      if @overrideGroupPermissions = 1

        SELECT @accessID = [Access_id]

        FROM [User_feature_access] [UFA]

        WHERE [UFA].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [UFA].[FeatureID] = @activityID

  END

 

  ---- get user access ID for activity

  --if @overrideGroupPermissions = 1 AND LEN(@activityID) > 0

  --   SELECT @accessID = [Access_id]

  --   FROM [User_feature_access] [UFA]

  --   WHERE [UFA].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [UFA].[FeatureID] = @activityID

 

  ---- if nothing for activity, get user access ID for function

  --IF @overrideGroupPermissions = 1 AND @accessID IS NULL AND LEN(@functionID) > 0

  --   SELECT @accessID = [Access_id]

  --   FROM [User_feature_access] [UFA]

  --   WHERE [UFA].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [UFA].[FeatureID] = @functionID

 

  ---- if nothing for function, get user access ID for module

  --IF @overrideGroupPermissions = 1 AND @accessID IS NULL

  --   SELECT @accessID = [Access_id]

  --   FROM [User_feature_access] [UFA]

  --   WHERE [UFA].[ObjectID] = @objectID AND [UFA].[FeatureID] = @moduleID

 

  SELECT @accessLevel = [Access_Level] FROM [Access_Type] WHERE [Access_id] = ISNULL(@accessID, @groupAccessId)

  RETURN ISNULL(@accessLevel, 0)

END

GO

 

-- Grant EXECUTE permission on User Function

 

IF OBJECT_ID(N'[dbo].[ufk3_EffectiveUserDatabasePermissions]', N'FN') IS NOT NULL

  GRANT EXECUTE ON [dbo].[ufk3_EffectiveUserDatabasePermissions] TO [JB_User]

GO

Fields in resultant recordsets correspond to those in data definition files. AR_Invoice_RptPref.ttx Data definition for columns from [dbo].[RptPref] table: Invoice_Head Invoice_Foot Company_Logo Invoice_QualDoc Invoice_QualAlign AR_Invoice_SalesTax.ttx Data definition for Sales Tax subreport JBW SIM Invoice Report Files Name Description AR_Invoice.rpt Report definition AR_Invoice.ttx Data definition for main report & Misc Charges subreport AR_Invoice_Rpt.htm Scripts to populate recordsets for use by report AR_Invoice_SalesTax.ttx Data definition for Sales Tax subreport Note JBW SIM Invoice Setup does NOT include the following, and the standard versions should be used: AR_Invoice_Flt.htm Report UI definition AR_Invoice_RptPref.ttx Data definition for [dbo].[RptPref] columns: Invoice_Head Invoice_Foot Company_Logo Invoice_QualDoc Invoice_QualAlign Additional Note The standard version of “AR_Invoice.ttx” does not include the fields contained in “AR_Invoice_RptPref.ttx”, whereas these fields are present in the JBW SIM Invoice version of “AR_Invoice.ttx”. Not sure if they ought to be removed from the JBW SIM Invoice version?? AR_Invoice Report Data Sources Report Subreport “AR_Invoice_MiscCharges_JobSO – 01” Subreport “AR_Invoice_SalesTax” Data Definition (TTX) Files From: http://www.crystalreportsbook.com/forum/forum_posts.asp?TID=14087 Configuring a report based on a Data Definition (TTX) file To report off runtime data sources contained in your project, your report must be based on a Data Definition (TTX) file. A Data Definition file is a tab separated text file, with a .ttx file extension, that is an outline of a table structure. Each line in a TTX file contains a field name, data type, length (if the data type is a string), and one piece of sample data. To create a report based on a Data Definition file using the Crystal report designer Open a new or existing report in the Crystal report designer. Open the Database Expert by clicking on the toolbar icon or selecting Database > Database Expert. Select Create New Connection > Field Definitions Only > Make New Connection. The Field Definitions Only dialog box opens. If you already have an existing TTX file that contains the data structure of your runtime data source, skip to step 7. Otherwise, continue to step 4 to create a TTX file based on the data structure of your runtime data source. Click Create File.... The Database Definitions Tool opens. Add the fields required to represent the runtime data source. For each field in your runtime data source, create a field entry in the TTX file by entering the name, type, length (if type is a String), and example data. Save the Data Definition file by selecting File > Save As and then choose a location for the TTX file. It is recommended that you save the file in your project workspace. Select a Data Definition file by clicking the Browse (...) button. You can now use the Data Definition file as a data source for an existing report or to create a new report. Once you have a report based on a Data Definition file, you can then use that report in your web application and push runtime data to the report. See Pushing runtime data to a report for details. Note: The data structure of the runtime data being pushed to a report must match the data structure defined in the Data Definition file. Data Definition (TTX) Files

From: http://www.crystalreportsbook.com/forum/forum_posts.asp?TID=14087

 

Configuring a report based on a Data Definition (TTX) file

To report off runtime data sources contained in your project, your report must be based on a Data Definition (TTX) file. A Data Definition file is a tab separated text file, with a .ttx file extension, that is an outline of a table structure. Each line in a TTX file contains a field name, data type, length (if the data type is a string), and one piece of sample data.


To create a report based on a Data Definition file using the Crystal report designer

  1. Open a new or existing report in the Crystal report designer.
  1. Open the Database Expert by clicking on the toolbar icon or selecting Database > Database Expert.
  1. Select Create New Connection > Field Definitions Only > Make New Connection.

The Field Definitions Only dialog box opens. If you already have an existing TTX file that contains the data structure of your runtime data source, skip to step 7. Otherwise, continue to step 4 to create a TTX file based on the data structure of your runtime data source.

  1. Click Create File....

The Database Definitions Tool opens.

  1. Add the fields required to represent the runtime data source.

For each field in your runtime data source, create a field entry in the TTX file by entering the name, type, length (if type is a String), and example data.

  1. Save the Data Definition file by selecting File > Save As and then choose a location for the TTX file. It is recommended that you save the file in your project workspace.
  1. Select a Data Definition file by clicking the Browse (...) button.

You can now use the Data Definition file as a data source for an existing report or to create a new report. Once you have a report based on a Data Definition file, you can then use that report in your web application and push runtime data to the report. See Pushing runtime data to a report for details.

Note:    The data structure of the runtime data being pushed to a report must match the data structure defined in the Data Definition file.
